components.text: You are classed as disabled under the Equality Act 2010 if you have a physical or mental impairment which has a ‘substantial’ and ‘long-term’ negative effect on your ability to do normal daily activities.

list_elements.text: 'substantial’ means the effect is more than minor or trivial, eg it takes much longer than it usually would to complete a daily task like getting dressed
‘long-term’ means the effect persist for 12 months or more, eg a breathing condition that develops as a result of a lung infection

components.text: A progressive condition is one that gets worse over time and people with progressive conditions can be classed as disabled.
However, you automatically meet the disability definition under the Equality Act 2010 from the day you’re diagnosed with HIV infection, cancer or multiple sclerosis.

myths.myth: It’s still ok to refer to people who do not have a disability as ‘able-bodied’?
myths.fact: No. This term suggests all disabilities are physical and that disabled employees or job applicants are not capable. Instead, if it is really necessary to make the distinction, use the term ‘non-disabled’ for people who do not have a disability.

myths.myth: To be disabled, the person has to be in a wheelchair, or blind, or lost a limb, something like that.
myths.fact: The definition of disability in the Equality Act 2010 is very broad and can cover a very wide range of conditions – what the law calls ‘impairments’. And some are not obvious – such as some mental health conditions.

components.text: Employers must make reasonable adjustments to ensure workers with disabilities, or physical or mental health conditions, aren’t substantially disadvantaged in their jobs. These adjustments may include:

list_elements.text: changing the recruitment process so a candidate can be considered for a job
doing things another way, such as allowing someone with social anxiety disorder to have their own desk instead of hot-desking
making physical changes to the workplace, such as installing a ramp for a wheelchair user or an audio-visual fire alarm for a deaf person
allowing  a disabled person to work somewhere else, such as on the ground floor for a wheelchair user
changing their equipment, for instance providing a special keyboard for a person with arthritis
allowing employees who become disabled to make a phased return to work, including flexible hours or part-time working
offering employees training opportunities, recreation and refreshment facilities

components.text: Reasonable adjustments apply to all employers and even should be considered  for students whilst on placements.

The Disabilities team and the Mental Health team at the university have lots of experience working with students who have disabilities. Please feel free to contact them for advice with any concerns you may have relating to workplace and the reasonable adjustments you may be able to make for students with a disability, SpLD or Mental Health needs. Please note we can only give specific student related advice if a student has disclosed their learning needs to us (see Disclosure-Procedure) and completed a data protection form.

It is the student’s choice to disclose their learning needs. For students who want to disclose, we recommend they do so at the earliest point: on their application form or contact the disabilities team. Disclosure means we can offer them support and advice and can discuss their needs and opportunities for adjustments with all those involved in their education.

It is an individual’s right not to disclose their learning needs. If a student chooses not to disclose, we are unaware of their condition and any related difficulties, therefore we are unable to offer support or advice.

sections.subtitle: Test Yourself: How much do you know about dyslexia?

components.text: Researchers know more and more about the causes and effects of dyslexia. But a few myths persist. Test yourself about knowlede on dyslexia using the quiz below. All answers are revealed when you finish the quiz, along with clarifications.

questions.text: Dyslexia is a sign of low IQ.
questions.tip: Dyslexia affects a cross section of people regardless of race, ethnicity, gender, age, intellectual level etc.  It is not an indication of low or high intelligence.

questions.text: People can grow out of dyslexia or be cured.
questions.tip: Dyslexia is not an illness, so it cannot be cured.  Dyslexia does not go away but the right support can help to alleviate its symptoms.

questions.text: There are more male than female dyslexics.
questions.tip: It was thought that 4:1 were males, but it is now believed to be 50/50%

questions.text: A person can’t be dyslexic if they read.
questions.tip: Not true.  Many dyslexic people enjoy reading.
This is not true however many dyslexics have a cross-laterality issue which can cause problems.

questions.text: If you’ve been to university, you can’t be dyslexic.
questions.tip: The number of university students with dyslexia has grown year on year.  There is DSA support available which makes a big difference.  It is not unusual for dyslexia to be identified for the first time at university.

components.subtitle: 2.2	What to do if a student comes to you to disclose
components.text: If a student discloses a disability to you, please advise them to make an appointment with a Disability Advisor. The disability advisor will discuss with them the information they need to provide, discuss support and other options available. Appointments can be made through the student portal and selecting ‘support at CU’. If unsure, the disability advisors can be contacted through emailing:

A student who has disclosed a disability, and had their disability verified, can receive various support from the disabilities team and their Learning Support Tutor (LST). Support from the disabilities team includes specialist tuition for study skills e.g. structuring paragraphs and reflective writing skills.
They may also be advised to apply for Disabled Student Allowance (DSA) which can include funding towards specialist equipment.
Where staff know about difficulties experienced, they can then make adjustments. However, some students may not want to disclose; it is their choice.

The University has an obligation to keep all sensitive information about students’ confidential. When a student provides information about a disability, condition, or other medical needs it will be treated with strict confidentiality. The University has confidentiality protection policies.

The Disability Team will hold all data students provide about their disability and you can decide who you need to share this information with. To discuss reasonable adjustments on placements, you will need share the information with teams and people on a “need to know” bases for example - the placement teams and the learning support tutor. You are not obliged to share the information. If you share the information, you will be supported by the various support teams and you will sign a disability disclosure agreement.

sections.subtitle: How information submitted to the Disability Team is stored

list_elements.text: Information held by the Disability Team about students will be held for 6 years in accordance with the Data Protection Act (1998). It is then disposed of securely.

All written records and files containing students' confidential details will be kept in a secure and locked environment. Student details are kept electronically on the secure databases. The records are accessible to authorised University staff. Under the Data Protection Act (1998) students have the right to access their own records.
Statistical information gathered for research, evaluation or monitoring purposes will be anonymous.

components.text: The University has an obligation to support students with disabilities. As soon as a student declares a disability, the University has a duty of care to support the student and offer reasonable adjustments. A student could decide to not disclose a disability.
Students listed on Universe as having a disability have submitted verification of their disability to the Disability team. If unsure contact the disability team or LST.

Learning in practice is usually unpredictable because it involves structuring a learning environment in a work place that is dynamic, challenging and sometimes, stressful. Students and educators/mentors share responsibility for learning. The educator/mentor is tasked with creating learning opportunities for the students as part of their primary role of delivering effective healthcare. The student is expected to have developed the theoretical knowledge necessary to engage with the learning and take responsibility for speaking to the educator about what is within their scope of practice. The complexity of challenging the student appropriately and supporting different learning styles is compounded by the workload.
Learning in clinical practice is challenging regarding organizational and pedagogical issues
components.author: Manninen

list_elements.text: Discuss the challenges of teaching and learning in practice setting.
Understand the Equality Act and what it means for the disabled student
Appreciate the need for reasonable adjustments and how they support students with a disability
Understand the support systems and mechanisms students with disabilities can access

components.text: The practice environment is primarily about meeting the needs of patients and ensuring clinical practice is safe and professional. Students are in the practice setting to learn, however, their education is a secondary feature of the learning environment. The educator/mentor will be doing their job and at the same time maximising opportunities to ensure students learn.

Educators and mentors typically expect students to be prepared for the practice environment (Clouder and Adefila 2017). At the University students will be exposed to a lot of a theoretical information, providing the background they need for learning on practice; educators and mentors provide the teaching in practice. In practice, students have the opportunity to acquire the skills of the profession and assess their learning.

Students with disabilities are often anxious about placements, this apprehension may result in mistakes or poor communication. Educators and mentors may not understand how students learn and do not often have the time to support students who need extra help. It is important that the educators and mentors are approachable and are able to encourage students to articulate their challenges clearly and honestly. A good educator/mentor-student relationship is essential for a successful placement.

The students and educator/mentors will need to negotiate all the challenges associated with teaching in the clinical/teaching environment. This means communicating, being responsive, approachable and professionally to work with your students.

When concerns arise about a student, whether this is about their competence, their behaviour or their professionalism, it is important to discuss your concerns as soon as possible with the individual. If your concerns escalate, you may need to refer these on to the University. The University may then determine if any further action is needed. This may involve referring the student for counselling, additional clinical support or for consideration of professional suitability and fitness to practice.

components.text: The Equality Act was introduced to simplify and strengthen discrimination laws across Britain. It harmonised 116 pieces of legislation. The aim of the legislation is to protect certain categories of people from unfair treatment.

components.subtitle: What is a disability under the Equality Act

list_elements.text: Age
Disability
Gender reassignment
Marriage and civil partnership
Race
Religion or belief
Sex
Sexual Orientation

components.subtitle: Direct discrimination
components.text: An individual or organisation that provides services to the public must not treat someone worse just because of one or more protected characteristics…

components.subtitle: Indirect discrimination
components.text: An organisation must not do something to someone in a way that has a worse impact on them and other people who share a particular protected characteristic than it has on people who do not share that characteristic. Unless the organisation can show that what they have done is objectively justified…

components.subtitle: Discrimination arising from disability
components.text: Service providers must not treat disabled people unfavourably because of something connected to their disability where they cannot show that what they are doing is objectively justified. This only applies if the individual or organisation knows, or could reasonably have been expected to know, that the person is disabled
A good summary of the Equality Act can be found at the link below:
The Equality Act allows for discrimination against any of the protected characteristics.

The Equality Act says discrimination can be justified if the person who's discriminating against you can show it’s a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim. If necessary, it's the courts which will decide if discrimination can be justified
components.author: Citizen’s advice website

components.text: A legitimate aim is the reason behind the discrimination. This reason must not be discriminatory in itself and it must be a genuine or real reason.
Here are some examples of legitimate aims:

list_elements.text: the health, safety and welfare of individuals
running an efficient service
requirements of a business
desire to make profit

myths.fact: An employer can dismiss a disabled employee if the dismissal is justified and they have taken all the correct steps.

myths.myth: Nobody thinks in stereotypes – we’re more sophisticated now.

components.text: Equality law identifies disabled people as one of eight protected categories in society. This means that the way society organises education, employment and access to recreation, etc. needs to be restructured to account for any barriers that may treat people with disabilities unfairly. In higher education, the law states it is the duty of institutions to provide students with disabilities reasonable adjustments.

components.subtitle: What is it?
components.text: Reasonable adjustments are very simply any alterations that need to be made to ensure a disabled person is not disadvantaged. However, the changes have to be considered reasonable. There are certain considerations that could be made when deciding if something is “reasonable”:
For example:

list_elements.text: How effective the change will be in avoiding the disadvantage the disabled worker would otherwise experience
Its practicality
Its cost
Your organisation’s resources and size
The availability of financial support.(GOV.UK website)

The work place is challenging and it is the students’ responsibility to ensure they are adequately prepared. However, some students may approach staff if they have challenging times.

This section will highlight some key tips for supporting students on placement. Placements are an unusual learning environment for students, and staff could provide reassurance and support to students who are struggling.

Provide the student with ongoing formative assessment of their performance in line with the outcomes/competencies they are expected to achieve.
Provide the student with formative assessment at the midpoint of their placement and a written summative assessment at the end of their placement.
Engage in lifelong learning/CPD
Evaluate their own mentorship activities.
Participate in the evaluation of their practice placement

components.text: Are you ready to have a student? The student will be coming to your organisation possibly for the first time and first impressions matter; they may set the tone for the entire placement. Students who feel welcome and sense that their educator is ready to support their learning typically have high rates of satisfaction and are more likely to have a successful placement.
This section will provide some suggestions on what you could do to prepare for a student coming on placement.

You should be aware of the students who will be coming on placement. 

Some students may contact the placement and may need to arrange a pre-placement visit. Some students may need to discuss Reasonable Adjustments. If you have any questions about students or how to respond to their needs, contact the University placement team for support.

How can a placement site or educator/mentor make a student feel welcome? 

It is important feel like the placement is genuinely ready and happy to have them. They have proper induction and staff are friendly and supportive.

components.subtitle: Setting placement goals
components.text:
Encourage the student to think about what they want to achieve. Students are advised to start a placement by thinking about what they want to achieve and how they could best achieve that. Some students will share their strengths with you and may be happy to discuss particular areas they want to develop. 

It is important to make the goals explicit, so you both know what you are working towards and how you can assess the success of the placement. Things may not go exactly as planned but having a plan helps to focus your energies. 

Students will also benefit if you tell them how you will be giving them feedback and how you expect from them.

components.subtitle: Professionalism
components.text:
Students are valued on placement because they can contribute to patient care and service delivery.

Students who feel that they are part of the team and valued are more likely to have a good experience and successful placement (Paterson, 1997).

Communicate with students professionally and be clear they understand how to be a professional.

components.subtitle: Support for educator or mentor
components.text: It is important that educators and mentors take care of themselves. When working with students, particularly if you are supporting a students who is struggling, seek help from your colleagues and line managers. Collaboration and collegiality can help you stay objective and professional. Colleagues may also be able to provide innovative methods of supporting the student.
